thread.title: US existing-home sales rebound in September
thread.title_full: US existing-home sales rebound in September

title: US existing-home sales rebound in September
text:
View Photo 

The US housing market, a bright spot in the economy, showed resilient growth in September as existing-home sales rebounded even as tight supply and rising home prices curb demand. 
Sales of previously owned homes jumped 4.7 percent to an annual rate of 5.55 million units with gains seen in all four major regions of the country, the National Association of Realtors (NAR) said Thursday. 
Home sales regained their momentum last month, marking the 12th straight year-over-year increase with an 8.8 percent rise. 
The September jump in sales, following a dip in August, was stronger than expected. Most analysts had estimated a rise to a pace of 5.39 million units. 
Lawrence Yun, NAR chief economist, highlighted incentives such as a slight moderation in home prices in some markets and mortgage rates holding near historic lows below four percent. 
"September home sales bounced back solidly after slowing in August and are now at their second highest pace since February 2007," he said. 
"While current price growth around six percent is still roughly double the pace of wages, affordability has slightly improved since the spring and is helping to keep demand at a strong and sustained pace." 
The median price for all previously owned housing types in September was $221,900, a gain of 6.1 percent from a year ago. In August the price was $228,500. 
Inventory tightened further in September, falling 2.6 percent to 2.21 million homes for sale. At the current sales pace, inventory stood at a 4.8-month supply, down from 5.1 months in August, NAR said. 
US house prices rose 0.3 percent in August, following a 0.5 percent rise in July, the Federal Housing Finance Agency reported Thursday. Year-over-year house prices were up 5.5 percent. 
Barclays (LSE: BARC.L - news ) analyst Blerina Uruci said that continued labor market improvements, including rising employment and a modest gain in wage growth, should bolster housing demand. 
"As a result, we expect the housing market to continue recovering at a moderate pace," Uruci said. 
The Federal Reserve has pointed to improvement in the housing market as an engine for growth in the economy as it moves toward raising its key interest rate.
